I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Development progress in the Pacific region is not encouraging. Economic growth has 
averaged less than 1% per capita annually over the past 30 years. Critical investments in basic 
infrastructure and human potential (such as health and education) have lagged well behind needs. 
Poverty is a hard and growing reality for many. Youth unemployment is high and rising, fueling the 
inevitable social strains. Skilled professionals increasingly seek better opportunities abroad, and in-
country migration to towns is growing, even when good opportunities do not exist. 
 
2.  In  Pacific  developing  member  countries  (PDMCs),  concerned  leaders  in  government, 
business, and civil society are increasingly questioning existing policies and institutions and their 
ability to support long-term economic growth that would lead to income opportunities, jobs, and the 
provision of essential services. Their reservations have triggered significant discussion of private 
sector development (PSD) reform in recent years, and have increased the demand for fresh 
thinking and new solutions. PSD now features prominently in policy dialogue, regional declarations, 
and reform initiatives.  
 
3.  PSD analysis and benchmarking, especially the private sector assessments (PSAs) of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)1 and  Doing  Business2 surveys  by  the  World  Bank  and  the 
International  Finance  Corporation,  have  elevated  the  level  of  awareness,  understanding,  and 
public debate of the underlying issues, as well as the positive relationship between private-sector-
led economic growth and poverty reduction. Development partners have been responding to such 
developments with an increased focus of resources on PSD.3 In particular, ADB has elevated PSD 
as a major thrust in its Pacific Strategy 2005–2009.4 
 
4.  However, PSD diagnostic studies and regional consultations indicate that imperatives of aid 
effectiveness  and  development  results  require  (i)  strengthened  economic  analysis  in  country 
strategies within the context of the constraints to PSD, (ii) the identification of more effective ways 
to deliver economic growth results, and (iii) improved partnership mechanisms with governments 
and  the  private  sector,  and  among  development  partners.  The  proposed  regional  technical 
assistance (TA) will strengthen the expertise and resources required to deliver these outcomes. 
The TA framework is in Appendix 1.5

II.  ISSUES 
5.  The low levels of competitiveness, investment, and economic growth in the Pacific region 
are largely due to the high costs of doing business and the inadequacies of institutions.6 Common 
PSD issues and challenges facing many PDMCs include (i) the pervasive role of the state in many 
aspects of economic activity, thereby inadvertently exacerbating rather than ameliorating problems 
associated with size and geographical isolation; (ii) the failure of financial markets to intermediate 
efficiently and provide access to credit for the private sector, especially in rural areas; (iii) business 
laws and regulations that are outdated and inadequate to support modern business transactions; 
and (iv) inefficient, unreliable, and often expansive infrastructure and services, often provided by 
state-owned enterprises (SOEs), which place an unnecessary burden on business. 
 
6.  While PSD advocacy and reform activities by ADB and other development partners in these 
priority areas have created a tangible reform momentum, translating this into development results 
is still in its infancy. Transforming the high profile discussion into effective policy change and, 
ultimately, higher growth and greater prosperity in the region remains a challenge. Issues and 
solutions are still imperfectly understood by policy makers, civil society, and even the private sector 
and  development  partners.  Vested  interests  often  oppose  meaningful  change,  while  reform 
champions often do not receive the necessary support. 
 
7.  Placing the private sector at the heart of the economy will require major efforts on the part 
of governments. In partnership with other agencies, ADB must find ways to support the necessary 
change processes and dynamics. Diagnostic studies, policy dialogue, advisory work and capacity 
development, supported by effective communications strategies, are instrumental ingredients of an 
effective PSD assistance strategy. The translation of reform recommendations into action must be 
facilitated through continuous engagement and dialogue, and effective change management. The 
private sector needs to be engaged, as it must play a crucial role in investment, innovation, and job 
creation. The communication gap between governments and the private sector in many PDMCs 
must  be  bridged.  Reform  champions  in  government,  business,  and  civil  society  should  be 
supported.  Moreover,  the  capacity  to  rapidly  respond  to  reform  opportunities  needs  to  be 
developed. There is a risk that the momentum may fade away unless appropriate action is taken. 
 
8.  ADB has established substantial PSD expertise, a body of knowledge based on PSAs and 
other assessments, a strong PSD focus in regional and country strategies, and operational PSD 
experience. ADB proposes to further expand its strategic, programmatic, and implementation focus 
in this area, both regionally and at country level, as committed in ADB’s Pacific Strategy 2005–
2009. With its sectoral expertise and multilateral structure, ADB can serve as an effective partner 
for PDMCs and development partners in initiating, implementing, and coordinating PSD-related 
analysis, policy dialogue, capacity development, and reform design and implementation, towards 
the outcome of a substantial improvement of the business environment in the region. Moreover, 
ADB is well placed to continually monitor and evaluate PSD reform progress, thereby ensuring that 
lessons are incorporated in future program and project design.  
 
9.  The proposed TA provides the framework and resources necessary to allow a degree of 
localization,  responsiveness,  flexibility,  and  coordination  and  cooperation  as  economic  reform 
opportunities arise in specific PDMCs and throughout the region.

III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  In line with ADB’s Pacific Strategy 2005–2009 and Private Sector Development Strategy,7 
the TA will contribute to poverty reduction in PDMCs by promoting enterprise, investment, and 
economic growth—as measured by improved trends in private sector investment and economic 
growth rates. Towards this end, the TA aims at improving the business environment by promoting 
effective  PSD  policies,  strategies,  practices,  and  activities  in  priority  areas—as  measured  by 
improved ratings in selected “Doing Business” indicators (footnote 2), and ongoing qualitative 
assessments through ADB PSAs. An increase in the number of quality public–private dialogues 
and partnerships, an important indicator of improved processes, will also be targeted. 
 
11.  The TA will augment ADB’s capacity to respond rapidly and strategically, and within the 
context of country strategies, to PDMCs’ unique PSD reform needs and emerging priorities. The 
TA  will  provide  short-term  expertise  on  critical  business  environment  issues  and  longer-term 
engagement on sustainable capacity development. The TA is designed to add substantial value to 
ADB’s regular PSD work by (i) supplementing the relatively limited ADB TA resources for PSD in 
the Pacific; (ii) increasing the breadth, depth, responsiveness, and effectiveness of ADB’s capacity 
to manage and deliver a PSD program in PDMCs; (iii) amplifying the engagement with PDMCs in 
terms  of  policy  dialogue,  knowledge  management,  and  technical  support;  and  (iv)  providing 
ongoing evaluation of reform programs with a view to sharpen future reform initiatives. The TA will 
augment ADB’s staff skills, and financial and technical resources dedicated to the implementation 
of ADB’s Pacific Strategy 2005–2009.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  In line with PSA findings and ADB’s Pacific Strategy 2005–2009, the TA will focus on, but 
not be restricted to, the following core themes: 
 
(i)  SOE reform and public–private partnerships8—focusing on government policies on 
SOEs (relating to ownership, performance, and divestment), economic regulation, 
legal framework and opportunities for public–private partnerships, privatization, and 
SOE corporate governance; 
(ii)  financial sector reform—focusing on secured transactions frameworks, rural and 
microfinance, financial sector outreach, financial products and services, and partial 
credit guarantees;9 
(iii)  institutional,  legal,  and  regulatory  business  environment—focusing  on  reforming 
business law and strengthening property rights;10 and 
(iv)  sectoral mainstreaming of PSD. 
 
13.  Activities related to the core themes will be carried out using a mix of country-focused, 
multi-country,  and  regional  approaches  and  processes  in  the  following  three  main  output 
categories:

(i)  Diagnostic studies, dialogue, and communication. A series of diagnostic studies 
on relevant PSD issues, strategies, and approaches will be undertaken, with a view 
to strengthen country PSD strategies, promote and underpin policy dialogue, trigger 
and inform reform action, and disseminate the findings to relevant stakeholders and 
the general public. A strategic framework for communication and dialogue will be 
developed to disseminate information on regional and international “good practice” 
PSD policy, approaches, and achievements; increase awareness and stakeholder 
dialogue on economic growth issues, including the links with poverty reduction; and 
improve media coverage of PSD issues.  
(ii)  Rapid  response,  technical  advice,  and  capacity  development.  The  TA  will 
enable  ADB  to  rapidly  respond  to  reform  opportunities  and  support  reform 
champions. Short-term technical expertise will be provided in priority reform areas 
(core themes) in supplementation and amplification of ADB country strategies and 
programs. Due attention will be given to capacity development of government and 
private sector organizations in PSD assessment, policy and strategy formulation, 
and reform implementation. 
(iii)  Regional  initiatives  and  monitoring.  With  a  view  to  promoting  regional 
cooperation and integration, support will be provided to regional PSD forums and 
initiatives.  Links  to  the  Pacific  Islands  Forum  Secretariat,  including  the  annual 
Forum Economic Ministers Meetings, and the new Pacific Islands Private Sector 
Organization,  representing  national  private  sector  organizations,  will  be  sought. 
Support  will  also  be  provided  for  the  implementation  of  the  Pacific  Plan  for 
Strengthening Regional Cooperation and Integration (Pacific Plan). In addition, a 
performance-monitoring system in support of pursuing development effectiveness 
will be established under the TA. 
 
14.  All  PDMCs  will  be  eligible  to  participate  in  the  TA  upon  request.11 TA  resources  will 
primarily focus on PDMCs that are committed to PSD reform and have the capacity to effectively 
absorb related assistance. Some consideration may be given to PSD issues and solutions in 
weakly performing PDMCs, taking into account the importance of economic growth for job creation 
and delivery of services in fragile country environments. In all cases, the respective ADB country 
strategy  and  program  and  ADB’s  Pacific  Strategy  2005–2009,  will  be  the  entry  point  for 
consideration of subprojects to be financed under the TA. 
 
15.  The TA will proactively seek cooperation and coordination with multilateral agencies and 
facilities active in PSD or related areas (e.g., with the World Bank, Foreign Investment Advisory 
Services [FIAS], Pacific Enterprise Partnership [PEP], and Pacific Financial Technical Assistance 
Centre [PFTAC]), as well as bilateral partners. Development partners will be engaged at project, 
country, regional, and institutional levels. An existing funding agency working group on PSD in the 
Pacific will be instrumental in ensuring effective strategic coordination.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $8,700,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a 
grant basis, $1,100,000 by ADB's TA funding program and $7,600,000 by the Government of 
Australia, with the latter amount to be administered by ADB. Participating PDMC governments will 
contribute  to  the  costs  of  activities  through  the  provision  of  counterpart  staff  salaries,  office 
accommodation, local transport, support services, and facilitation of consultations. Detailed cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
                                                 
11  No TA funds will be disbursed for any subproject without ADB first obtaining approval or “no objection” from the PDMC 
for the RETA and the specific subproject to be financed thereunder.

5
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The TA will be implemented by ADB. ADB’s Pacific Department (PARD) will be responsible 
for all TA activities. The TA office will be established in, and managed by, ADB’s Pacific Liaison 
and Cooperation Office (PLCO). PSD programming support, subproject design and implementation, 
as well as monitoring and reporting will be undertaken by PLCO, supported by TA consultants. The 
implementation  of  TA  activities  may  be  delegated  to  other  ADB  offices.  PARD’s  regional 
management team (RMT), led by the director general, will provide strategic and tactical guidance. 
RMT approval of design and implementation arrangements will be required for TA subprojects 
exceeding $500,000. RMT may seek advice and engagement from relevant ADB departments or 
offices. While ADB will be solely responsible in managing the identification and implementation of 
project  activities  within  the  framework  of  its  individual  country  strategies,  participating  PDMC 
governments, the private sector, and other development partners will be engaged and consulted. 
 
18.  Effective  and  efficient  process  management  and  coordination  mechanisms  will  be 
established, including a performance tracking and reporting system for development effectiveness. 
TA progress reports will be prepared on a regular basis. A comprehensive TA mid-term review will 
be  carried  out.  Project-related  information,  reports,  and  other  relevant  documentation  will  be 
published on a dedicated Website.  
 
19.  The TA will have a term of 5 years and will be implemented from December 2006 to 
November 2011. The implementation of TA activities will require the services of international 
consultants (up to 250 person-months) and national consultants (up to 100 person-months). The 
outline  terms  of  reference  are  in  Appendix  3.  The  consultants  will  be  engaged  by  ADB  in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. While the TA will use a mix of 
individual consultants and consulting firms, preference may be given to recruiting consulting firms 
to enable coordination of the inputs of the various experts.12 Equipment and materials to be 
financed under the TA will be procured by the consultants or by ADB in accordance with ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
20.  The President recommends that the Board approve (i) ADB administering a portion of 
technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $7,600,000 to be financed on a grant basis by 
the Government of Australia, and (ii) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of 
$1,100,000 on a grant basis, for the Private Sector Development Initiative. 
                                                 
12   Consultant assignments and associated expertise and outputs will be determined on the basis of local demand for, 
and hence nature of, relevant reform initiatives. The required expertise may be highly diverse and specialized, and 
the same expertise may simultaneously be needed in several PDMCs.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The outline terms of reference for consultants describe the main tasks in each of the output 
categories of the program of activities under the technical assistance (TA), as well as support in 
project  management.  The  three  output  categories  are  (i)  diagnostic  studies,  dialogue,  and 
communication; (ii) rapid response, technical advice, and capacity development; and (iii) regional 
initiatives  and  monitoring.  The  Pacific  Liaison  and  Coordination  Office  (PLCO)  of  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) will coordinate the program of activities. The required areas of expertise 
for international and national experts include (i) private sector development (PSD) strategies and 
policies,  (ii)  institutional  change,  (iii)  state-owned  enterprise  (SOE)  reform,  (iv)  public–private 
partnerships, (v) legal and regulatory reform, (vi) financial sector development, (vii) capacity building, 
(viii) knowledge management and communication, (ix) information systems, and (x) PSD monitoring 
and evaluation. 
 
2.  Detailed  terms  of  reference  will  be  formulated  as  concrete  subprojects  materialize. 
Subprojects will be determined as the work plan is developed under the TA. Upon TA approval, 
consideration will be given to inputs from key stakeholders, to reform opportunities that arise, and to 
positively assessed requests for support. All proposals for support will be assessed against decision 
criteria  including  (i)  relevance  and  potential  of  the  proposed  reform  measure  from  the  PSD 
perspective, (ii) PSD potential in the country concerned, (iii) complementary nature to ADB country 
strategy and program, (iv) government reform ownership, (v) existence of local reform champions, 
(vi) potential to trigger or leverage broader reform measures (beyond the specific proposal), and (vii) 
funding agency coordination. Proposals for TA support can be submitted directly by governments of 
Pacific developing member countries (PDMCs) and by key stakeholders through their government. 
They can also be triggered by ADB, e.g., by country desks or sector desks in need of PSD support. 
 
A.  Diagnostic Studies, Dialogue, and Communication 
3.  A series of diagnostic studies on relevant PSD issues, strategies, and approaches will be 
undertaken, with a view to strengthen country PSD strategies, promote and underpin policy dialogue, 
trigger and inform reform action, and disseminate the findings to relevant stakeholders and the 
general public. Diagnostic studies will focus either on large economy-wide issues, for instance 
private sector assessments, or on the core themes of (i) SOE reform and public–private partnerships; 
(ii) financial intermediation; (iii) business law and regulation; and (iv) mainstreaming of PSD, as well 
as in other relevant issues concerning critical PSD issues, strategies, and practices at the country 
and regional levels. Relevant PSD expertise will be required to help strengthen individual country 
strategies and programs in their PSD focus and by mainstreaming PSD.  
 
4.  The TA will recruit PSD experts with backgrounds in economics, business administration, or 
law, and with experience in the analysis of enabling conditions for PSD and economic growth, the 
examination  of  the  microeconomic  impact  of  reform  on  the  private  sector,  and  the  design  of 
government-led reform processes. The experts will have extensive experience in the areas of (i) 
SOE-related policy, strategy, corporate governance, and reform processes, as well as public–private 
partnerships; (ii) financial sector development; (iii) legal and regulatory analysis; and (iv) formulation 
and implementation of related reform processes. The experts will help assess PSD issues in PDMCs; 
promote PSD practices, policies, and strategies at country and regional levels; provide and integrate 
PSD  diagnoses  and  reform  recommendations  in  the  context  of  ADB  country  strategies  and 
programs; promote effective strategic links with development partners; formulate reform measures 
and translate these into project activities; coordinate TA inputs and activities with participating 
PDMC governments, local stakeholders, and other development partners; monitor and report on 
project  progress  and  development  results.  The  experts  will  be  strong  team  players  and  have 
excellent communication skills.

5.  International communication expert(s) will be engaged under the TA to (i) help develop a 
strategic framework for PSD communication and dialogue, with a view to disseminate information 
and  knowledge  concerning  proven  PSD  policy,  approaches,  and  achievements;  (ii)  increase 
awareness and stakeholder dialogue on economic growth issues; and (iii) improve media coverage 
of PSD issues locally and regionally. Expertise will be required to help implement the strategic 
framework, with special attention to work undertaken under the TA in terms of diagnostic work and 
technical advice on country and regional levels. This will include establishing and capitalizing on 
links  with  regional  initiatives  and  forums.  Expertise  will  also  be  required  for  the  editing  and 
publication of reports, policy notes, opinion editorials, etc.  
 
B.  Rapid Response, Technical Advice, and Capacity Development 
6.  The TA will enable ADB to rapidly respond to PSD reform opportunities and support reform 
champions. Short-term technical expertise will be provided in priority reform areas (core themes) in 
supplementation  and  amplification  of  ADB  country  and  regional  strategies  and  programs.  Due 
attention will be given to capacity development of government and private sector organizations in 
PSD assessment, policy and strategy formulation, and reform implementation. 
 
7.  The TA will recruit PSD experts, economists, and business law experts with experience in 
the  analysis  of  enabling  conditions  for  PSD  and  economic  growth,  the  examination  of  the 
microeconomic  impact  of  reform  on  the  private  sector,  and  the  design  and  implementation  of 
government-led reform processes. Upon government request, expert(s) will be dispatched to assess 
relevant  PSD  issues,  develop  reform  strategies  and  approaches,  and  implement  specific  PSD 
reform measures that complement the respective ADB country strategy and program. Short-term 
expertise may also be provided, for instance, to identify and help catalyze strategic opportunities for 
private sector investment at country or regional level, possibly through public–private partnerships. 
Short-term expertise may also be used to support dialogue between governments and businesses in 
specific  PDMCs  or  regionally.  Finally,  the  TA  will  provide  expertise  for  the  development  and 
implementation of new and innovative approaches (pilot projects) in PSD reform, in support of 
PDMC governments and private sector organizations.  
 
8.  The seasoned PSD experts will comprise generalists and specialists in one or more of the 
TA’s core themes. They will have excellent communication and dialogue skills, and team leadership 
qualities. 
 
C.  Regional Initiatives and Monitoring 
9.  With a view to promote regional cooperation and integration, support will be provided to 
regional PSD forums and initiatives. Links to the Pacific Islands Forum Secretariat, including the 
annual Forum Economic Ministers Meeting, and the new Pacific Islands Private Sector Organization, 
will be sought. Support will also be provided for the implementation of the Pacific Plan. 
 
10.  Consultants will be engaged to (i) facilitate regional workshops, seminars, and conferences; 
(ii) support relevant regional PSD project or program initiatives; (iii) establish or strengthen links 
between  the  TA  and  regional  initiatives  and  events;  and  (iv)  contribute  to  regional  integration 
processes, for instance the Pacific Plan, in PSD areas.  
 
11.  Monitoring  and  evaluation  expert(s)  will  be  engaged  to  (i)  assist  in  the  design  and 
implementation of a monitoring and reporting system covering TA inputs, outputs, outcomes, and 
financial management, with links to existing ADB systems and databases; (ii) design and establish 
an evaluation system, including performance indicators; (iii) help monitor performance and assess 
development impact; and (iv) assist in developing a reporting format. The design and maintenance 
of the project website may also be outsourced.
